posts.name: rahilm
posts.cooked:
When deploying robot code (python), the rio canbus seems to not be available. Our Canivore loop is fine during this time. The symptom is lots of stale CAN frame errors in Driverstation (corresponding to all the IDs on that loop). Looking at Tuner, we see the same with none of the Rio loop devices visible.

After restarting robot code, normal behavior resumes

We’ve checked and all our packages are up to date. Any thoughts or do we just continue using the workaround?

posts.name: Juliette Johnson
posts.cooked: So occasionally you’ll upload and not have all your motors? We are experiencing this same issue with a can bus as well

posts.name: kylelanman
posts.cooked: In python It doesn’t fully terminate the previous version of code before starting up the new and it struggles to attach to the CAN bus.  We fought it last year on python.  We switched to Java this year.  It is annoying in the shop but it always works on boot so not a problem at competition.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: We fixed it last year in the same way that Java fixed it, but I hadn’t heard that it was still broken. Will have to look into it.

posts.name: rahilm
posts.cooked:
Came across the post with the fix from last year as well, so I thought we were doing something wrong.

Thanks for looking into it and please let me know if there’s any other info we can provide

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
I don’t have the hardware to reproduce this, but it seems that GradleRIO kills the robot program before it does a deploy. This PR does that too, please try it out: Kill the robot before copying files by virtuald · Pull Request #138 · robotpy/robotpy-installer · GitHub

You can install it via:

link_counts.title: Kill the robot before copying files by virtuald · Pull Request #138 · robotpy/robotpy-installer · GitHub

posts.name: rahilm
posts.cooked: We just gave it a shot, but still seeing the same behavior. Confirmed with pip list that we’re running the correct version

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
Hm. I made a different branch with verbose logging.

Please install that, and when it fails, copy the text here. It should have lots of + in the output.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Were you able to get the more verbose output?

posts.name: rahilm
posts.cooked: Apologies for the delay. Added the more verbose output here:

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Thanks for the updated log. We might have a fix? Try this version of robotpy-installer.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: That branch no longer exists – but its contents are in robotpy-installer 2025.1.0, which we theorize might help with your issue. Let us know if it makes a difference!

posts.name: rahilm
posts.cooked: We managed to pull that branch and test it while at competition this past weekend, but were still running into the same thing. We’ll try 2025.1.0 as well this week to see if that helps
